de.humatic.nmj

Class NMJConfig

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.humatic.nmj.NMJConfig

  • public class NMJConfig
extends java.lang.Object
    This is the main configuration interface for nmj network midi channels. Configurations are stored in java preferences (SharedPreferences on Android) and will be recalled on subsequent library loads without requiring further interaction.

    The configuration is valid no matter if you use nmj as a javax.sound SPI or via its public api. The javax.sound SPI will present MidiDevice.Info objects and MidiDevices based on this information, the public (and Android) api will let you access and use channels based on it.

    nmj will mostly not directly deal with hardware. The channels it offers are best understood as virtual: You set up some configuration - say for example two RTP and two Bluetooth channels - and these channels will then be available to your application. During runtime additional channels may be defined and become available to applications as a result of DNS service discovery, Bluetooth or ADB scans. These will be persisted in the preferences as well and it is application's choice whether it wants to keep them stored or wants to remove them on exit.
    Long as no user or app configuration is present, the library will present three default channels: Two ipMIDI compatible multicast channels (one input and one output) plus a bidrectional RTP channel. These are not set in stone. You can delete or reconfigure all of them and adjust everything.to your needs. Typically an application will store a desired configuration on the first run and reuse that.

    • Method Detail

      • setApplicationNode

        public static void setApplicationNode(java.lang.String fullyQualifiedPackageName)
        Redirects storage to an application specific preferences node. Should be called early and on every run of an application as the value holding the path (not the values stored under that path) might be overwritten by other applications.
        This method does nothing on Android, where application specific SharedPreferences are used anyway.

      • setNumChannels

        public static void setNumChannels(int nr)
        Sets the total number of channels that the library will provide. If the new number is smaller than the currently set number of channels, configuration data for those channels no longer needed is deleted.

      • setNumChannels

        public static void setNumChannels(int nr,
                  boolean clear)
        Sets the total number of channels that the library will provide. If the new number is smaller than the currently set number of channels, configuration data for those channels no longer needed is optionally deleted and channels newly created after this will be initialized with default settings.

      • getNumChannels

        public static int getNumChannels()
        Returns the total number of channels currently configured.

      • addChannel

        public static int addChannel()
        Increments the channel count by 1 and returns the newly created channels id.

      • cleanup

        public static int[] cleanup(int defChannels,
            int[] protectedChannels)
        Removes discovered remote channels. This is a convenience method that would usually be called on program exit. nmj will store discovered remote channels of all sorts in its preferences and they will remain there until deleted. For many applications it may not be necessary to permanently keep information on remote peers as they will usually be rediscovered on the next run. This method can remove everything in one call, optionally keeping some channel:
        %defChannels - the id of your highest index default channel. Channels with an id <= this will be kept.
        %protectedChannels - an array of ids of remote channels that you want to keep. These will not be deleted, but may be relocated to keep channel ids in successive order. New ids will be returned in an equally sized array.

      • setIP

        public static void setIP(int ch,
         java.lang.String ip)
                  throws NMJException
        Sets the IP address for the given channel. Note that the IP field is also used to store Bluetooth addresses, ADB device IDs and Usb product / vendor IDs. You will most likely only use this method when explicitely defining some sort of WIFI channel. Remote channels will have their IP set on device discovery. To create a local RTP session set its IP to null.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • getIP

        public static java.lang.String getIP(int ch)
                              throws NMJException
        Returns a channel's remote IP address (null for local RTP sessions).
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • setPort

        public static void setPort(int ch,
           int port)
                    throws NMJException
        Sets the remote port number for the given channel.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • getPort

        public static int getPort(int ch)
                   throws NMJException
        Returns a channel's remote port.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • setLocalPort

        public static void setLocalPort(int ch,
                int port)
                         throws NMJException
        Sets the local port number for the given channel (unicast and RTP mode only).
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • getLocalPort

        public static int getLocalPort(int ch)
                        throws NMJException
        Returns a channel's local port (unicast and RTP mode only).
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • setBasePort

        public static void setBasePort(int mode,
               int p)
        Sets the portnumber that local ports for RTP channels will be based on (first channel will use p and p+1, channel n will use p+n*2 and p+n*2+1). Default is 6500 and there should be no need to change this unless you want to run two programs making use of nmj in parallel on one machine / device. In that case call this once in the very beginning.

      • setMode

        public static void setMode(int ch,
           int mode)
                    throws NMJException
        Sets a channel's operation mode. Currently there are five modes defined:
        RAW - this runs raw midi bytes over ethernet, can run both uni- and multicast and is compatible with ipMidi and Midi2Net.
        RTPA - uses RTP for transport and Apple's proprietary Network MIDI protocol for session establishment and maintenance. When setting a channel to RTPA mode it will initially be configured as a session that the local machine makes available to others (getIP() will return null for it). Sessions from other machines will usually be created upon service discovery, but can also be configured manually by setting a channel to RTPA mode and specifying non null IP addresses and remote port numbers.
        BLUETOOTH - runs MIDI over Bluetooth between the desktop and Android versions of nmj.
        DSMI - sends MIDI via the DSMidiWifi server.
        ADB - for communicating with nmj running on a USB connected Android device via the Android Debug Bridge (Requires the Android SDK tools to be available on the desktop machine and the Android device to have USB debugging enabled).
        Android only:
        USB_HOST - runs MIDI over class compliant USB MIDI interfaces connected to Android tablets supporting USB host mode (requires Android 3.1 or greater).
        On Android this method may throw IllegalArgument and SecurityExceptions.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • getMode

        public static int getMode(int ch)
                   throws NMJException
        Returns the channel's operation mode (RAW, RTPA, ADB etc.).
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • setNetworkAdapter

        public static void setNetworkAdapter(int ch,
                     int index)
                              throws NMJException
        Sets the network interface to bind sockets to by index into the enumeration returned from java.net.NetworkInterface.getNetworkInterfaces(). This is usually not required as the library will attempt to figure out what the default adapter is, but on multi-homed systems it may be necessary or desired to specify the network adapter for multicast channels.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • getNetworkAdapter

        public static int getNetworkAdapter(int ch)
                             throws NMJException
        Returns the index of the channel's explicitely set or default network interface.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • setIO

        public static void setIO(int ch,
         int io)
                  throws NMJException
        Sets the given (multicast) channel to input (0) or output (1). Does nothing for channels with mode != RAW.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • getIO

        public static int getIO(int ch)
                 throws NMJException
        Returns 0 if the given channel is set as an input, 1 for output and -1 for bidirectional channels. javax.sound.midi.MidiDevice.getMaxTransmitters() and getMaxReceivers() will accordingly return -1 or 0.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • setFlags

        public static void setFlags(int ch,
            int flags)
        Controls additional aspects, like autoconnection settings, service discovery etc. For global flags use -1 for the channel parameter. This method may also initialize or abort actions and should therefore be called with a value for %flags that is a combinaton of all desired bits.
        Valid gloabal flags are:
        DNS_QUERY - listen for other machines session announcements,
        DNS_ANNOUNCE - announce own sessions,
        DNS - combination of both.
        Long as none of the DNS related flags has been explicitly set or cleared, DNS will run in full.
        LOOPBACK - without this services originating from the local machine will be ignored in DNS.
        DEL_15 - delete previously seen sessions after 15 minutes should they not have been (re)announced.
        DEL_30 - delete previously seen sessions after 30 minutes
        SHIFT_PORTS - allow the library to pick other then the given local ports should those be in use and unavailable
        . Channel specific flags:
        RTPA_AUTOCONNECT - connect an RTP Session when the corresponding MIDI channel is opened. Active by default.Toggling this also instructs newly created local sessions to start listening for invitations.

      • getFlags

        public static int getFlags(int ch)
        Returns global (if ch == -1) or a specific channel's control flags.

        public static void setName(int ch,
           java.lang.String userName)

      • setLocalClientPrefix

        public static void setLocalClientPrefix(java.lang.String pf)

      • getClientCount

        public static int getClientCount(int ch)
        Returns the number of clients that are currently connected to a local RTP session. If the channel at %ch is not a local RTP session the return will always be 0.

      • getClientPort

        public static int getClientPort(int ch,
                int id)
        Returns the port number on a client machine that connected to a local session. If no client with the given ID is found (or if the channel is not an RTP channel) the return will be -1.

      • getClientName

        public static java.lang.String getClientName(int ch,
                             int id)
        Returns the Bonjour name of a client that connected to a local RTP session.

      • getClientIP

        public static java.lang.String getClientIP(int ch,
                           int id)
        Returns the IP address of a client that connected to a local RTP session

      • disconnectClient

        public static void disconnectClient(int ch,
                    int clientID)
        Disconnects the given client from the local RTP session at %ch. Does nothing with non-RTP channels or RTP channels that aren't local sessions.

      • addSystemListener

        public static void addSystemListener(NMJSystemListener l)
        Adds a listener to be informed of state changes and errors in the system.

      • setProperty

        public static void setProperty(java.lang.String key,
               java.lang.String value)

      • getProperty

        public static java.lang.String getProperty(java.lang.String key,
                           java.lang.String def)

      • getConnectivity

        public static int getConnectivity(java.lang.Object android_content_Context)
        Android only.
        This method does nothing in J2SE context and is only in the source to avoid the necessity for two separate javadoc editions. On Android the Object argument needs to be an instance of android.content.Context. The correct documentation should therefore read: public static int getConnectivity(android.content.Context ctx)
        Returns a bitmask of CONNECTIVITY_... flags indicating what connection method will be available.

      • setBluetoothStackAdapter

        public static void setBluetoothStackAdapter(java.lang.String fullyQualifiedClassName)
        J2SE / desktop java only.
        Sets the Bluetooth adapter implementation to use. The given class must extend BluetoothStackAdapter and will be loaded via Class.foName(..) when channels set to BLUETOOTH mode are opened. See the BluetoothStackAdapter class for more details.

      • getBluetoothStackAdapter

        public static java.lang.String getBluetoothStackAdapter()

      • setBluetoothSystemListener

        public static void setBluetoothSystemListener(NMJBluetoothSystemListener btl)
        J2SE / desktop java only.
        Sets a listener to be informed on Bluetooth discovery events.

      • removeBluetoothSystemListener

        public static void removeBluetoothSystemListener(NMJBluetoothSystemListener btl)
        J2SE / desktop java only.
        Removes the given listener.

      • breakBluetoothQuery

        public static void breakBluetoothQuery()
        J2SE / desktop java only.
        Stop a running Bluetooth scan.

      • runBluetoothQuery

        public static void runBluetoothQuery(NMJBluetoothSystemListener btl)
                              throws java.lang.Exception
        J2SE / desktop java only.
        Start a Bluetooth scan.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • deleteChannel

        public static void deleteChannel(int ch)
        Removes the given channel, eventually closing its MIDI ports before.

      • resetAll

        public static void resetAll()
        Deletes all settings and reverts to the default state of two multicast channels plus one local RTP session

      • getVersionInfo

        public static java.lang.String getVersionInfo()
        Returns the library version as a String, for example 0.8

      • setDebugLevel

        public static void setDebugLevel(int level)
        Controls the verbosity of runtime debug messages. Default is 0 (so nothing will be printed).

      • setLogFile

        public static void setLogFile(java.io.File logFile,
              boolean append)
        Redirects debug output to the given file

      • showConfigDialog

        public static javax.swing.JDialog showConfigDialog(java.awt.Frame parent,
                                   java.lang.String dialogTitle)
        Deprecated. Deprecated method, use showConfigDialog(java.awt.Frame, String, int) instead.

      • showConfigDialog

        public static javax.swing.JDialog showConfigDialog(java.awt.Frame parent,
                                   java.lang.String dialogTitle,
                                   int flags)
        Brings up nmj's control panel as a child of the given frame (whose icon it will take) and with the given title. Both Frame and String arguments can be null. The flags parameter controls additional properties of the dialog. Currently only DLG_HIDDEN is defined. With that bit set, the dialog will not automatically show, so user code can reposition or customize the returned JDialog before making it visible.
        This method is not available on Android where the control panel is launched as a separate activity (see the sample project for details).
